poem:
California  
fires rage, red flag skies—  
the wind whispers  
of dry breath,  
tinder tales.  

Ten thousand homes  
vanish into a sigh,  
eleven souls small  
against the bright roar.  

Still, the sun rises—  
a relentless witness  
to ash  
and air,  
the soil remembering  
the language of flame.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "California fires: 11 killed and 10,000 structures destroyed as blazes continue Weather forecasters in Los Angeles were expecting fast, dry winds to return towards the end of the weekend, threatening to fuel wildfires that have already destroyed 10,000 structures and killed 11 people. Urgent “red flag” alerts – meaning critical fire weather conditions – announced by the US National Weather Service (NWS) said moderate to strong wind and low humidity would continue on Friday morning,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
